title: ‘So extraordinary it’s almost unbelievable’
text:
Email a friend 
DAVID Attenborough once described Lord Howe Island as “so extraordinary it is almost unbelievable … few islands, surely, can be so accessible, so remarkable, yet so unspoilt.” 
After five days spent exploring the island I, however, was definitely not unspoilt — I was fitter, but fatter, and completely in love with this secluded NSW paradise only two hours from Sydney. 
Flying in to Lord Howe Island has become the stuff of legends. When I mentioned I was going, everyone seemed to have an opinion on getting there — small plane, bumpy flight, tiny luggage allowance (14kgs) and in the middle of nowhere. I can safely say they were unfounded, except for the small plane and luggage, which actually set the scene for an epic adventure rather than detracting from it. 
After dropping down from the clouds, the towering mountains, Gower and Lidgbird, came into view. The island arcs around a 6km-long bright blue lagoon, bracketed by the most southern coral reef in the world. The water looks like it’s been ‘photoshopped’— it’s a saturated blue and like nothing I’ve seen before in Australia. It’s take-your-breath-away kind of beautiful and we couldn’t wait to get down there. It’s like something out of Jurassic Park. Picture: Stephanie Williams. Source: Supplied Standing on top of Malabar hill, looking towards the blue waters of Ned’s Beach. Picture: Stephanie Williams. Source: Supplied 
We’re spending the next week at Pinetrees, a lodge in the centre of the island that’s been welcoming guests since 1848. The owners Dani and Luke Hansen have recently completed a chic restoration of the property, and the place feels like new. 
Within half an hour of arriving, my partner, toddler and I are on our bikes and ready to explore. First stop is Ned’s Beach to feed the fish. One dollar buys a handful of fish food and about ten minutes of belly aching laughter for us — dropping fish food at each other’s feet attracting the many eager mullet and wrasse fish to shimmy around our legs. We’re keen to get hiking and spend the afternoon walking up Transit Hill, the peak in the centre of the island with views north and south, and friendly cows along the way. 
And then it’s time for the food. You would never guess that fresh produce is only delivered to the island once a fortnight. The Pinetress chef Alasdair Nicolson, ex-Grand National (Sydney), works wonders. The highlight of the week was definitely ‘fish fry’ night, where local kingfish and other seafood are transformed into generous sushi and sashimi platters, followed by grilled and battered fillets with a well-crafted salads and chips. Alasdair’s gorgeous wife Danielle (also a talented baker if you get along to the Sunday markets) is on hand to babysit, so we enjoy a few dinners baby-free too. The view from Kim’s lookout. The hike up the mountain was well worth it. Picture: Stephanie Williams. Source: Supplied Stephanie’s toddler enjoyed the reef from the safety of a glass bottomed boat. Picture: Stephanie Williams. Source: Supplied 
After a massive volcanic eruption seven million years ago, the island was colonised by plants from the surrounding regions (which were actually quite far away in Australia, New Zealand and New Caledonia) and seabirds flocked to make the island their breeding ground forever more. Lord Howe acted as a provisioning station for ships travelling between Sydney and Norfolk Island, and for whaling ships. The island was World Heritage listed in 1982 to preserve the rare flora and fauna that has continued to flourish. It helps that only 350 people live on Lord Howe and only another 400 are allowed to visit at any given time. 
Descendants of the first inhabitants still live on the island and real estate ownership is limited — if no islander wants to buy land up for sale, only then can a non-islander buy it. Eco-principles are strictly adhered to, and deliveries of food and supplies arrive by boat every fortnight. Bikes are the best way to get around and shoes feel optional by the time you’re heading home. 
Fifth generation islander Dean Hiscox took me for a dive in the lagoon one day, after briefing me about the “awesome” sharks I might see at Erscott’s hole. Eek. 
The reef is pristine, untouched and well managed. The colours are full on and the water is as clear as it is clean, and packed with so many colourful fish, including the endemic double header wrasse. For the record, a shark was spotted and I stayed calm — by this stage Lord Howe Island had me pretty relaxed. 
We enlist Danielle’s babysitting services and set ourselves free for a date afternoon at Capella Lodge — a five-star luxury resort in the foothills of the mountains. 
A gourmet lunch of local fish and chips with a cheeky white wine was punctuated by “that” view — soaring Mounts Gower and Lidgbird — moodily draped in misty fog. After lunch we took a peek at the ultra-luxe Lidgbird suite (it comes with it’s own golf buggy for island exploration) and stretched our legs on the gentle 3km walk to Little Island, through ancient forests of banyan trees and endemic kentia palms. 
From March to September, you can witness the incredibly rare Providence Petrels fly round the twin peaks here, and if you’re game you can try and call them down like David Attenborough did . The view from the rooms at Capella Lodge are out of this world. Picture: Stephanie Williams. Source: Supplied 
But the highlight of our whole trip was a simple walk, starting at Settlement Beach, hiking up to Kim’s Lookout with the most incredible views of the topography back down the island, then across Malabar Hill where we can see Ball’s Pyramid reaching 562 metres, like a natural obelisk rising out of nowhere 20kms offshore, and finishing with a barbecue at Ned’s Beach, with everything prepared and dropped off by Pinetrees. 
To me, it says everything about a family holiday here — the simple things really are the most enjoyable. I can safely say, Sir David was right, Lord Howe Island is extraordinary, and has to be experienced to be believed. Could there be a better spot for a family picnic? Picture: Stephanie Williams. Source: Supplied 
*The writer was a guest of Lord Howe Island Tourism Board and Pinetrees Lodge.
